displaytitle: Whistle in the form of a two-sided transformation figure
medium: Mold-made ceramic with traces of polychrome

titles.title: Whistle in the form of a two-sided transformation figure

texts.textentryhtml: This unique ceramic figurine presents a pairing of the human and supernatural, animal aspects of a Maya religious specialist.  The human figure’s squat proportions likely indicate that he was is an anacephalic dwarf.  Among the Maya, dwarves were considered to have a particularly strong connection to the supernatural, and often served as members of royal courts.  His blue feather costume and pot belly are typical features of depictions of religious speicalists or priests.  The other side of the figurine presents the animal alter-ego, or ‘way’ (pronounced ‘why’), of the human figure.  His body remains humanoid, however, and makes the identical gestue as the human figure on the other side.  Although not clearly identifiable, the animal alter-ego’s face may be that of a canine, a coatimundi, o a peccary, all of which were common creatures of the Maya region.  The hole on the figure’s shoulder served as a blow whole, as the figurine is a whistle.  This whistle may have been played by the person depicted when undergoing transformation into his alter-ego.

Possibly Peter Furst; acquired by Gillett G. Griffin (1928-2016), Princeton, NJ [1]; bequest to the Princeton University Art Museum, 2006.

[1] According to undated slides.

bibliography.boilertext: Dorie Reents-Budet, Painting the Maya Universe: Royal Ceramics of the Classic Period (Durham and London: Duke University Press, 1994).
bibliography.citation: Dorie Reents-Budet, Painting the Maya Universe: Royal Ceramics of the Classic Period (Durham and London: Duke University Press, 1994)., pp. 274, 355

bibliography.boilertext: Linda Schele, Hidden Faces of the Maya (Poway: ALTI Publishing, 1997).
bibliography.citation: Linda Schele, Hidden Faces of the Maya (Poway: ALTI Publishing, 1997)., pl. 3, p. 129 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: Harmer Johnson, ed. Guide to the Arts of the Americas (New York: Rizzoli, 1992)
bibliography.citation: Harmer Johnson, ed. Guide to the Arts of the Americas (New York: Rizzoli, 1992), p. 93 (illus.)

geography.displaygeography: Place excavated: North America, Mexico, Campeche, Maya area, said to be from Jaina Island
geography.locale: said to be from Jaina Island
